reviews.title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Unbeatable price/performance! Has 3.5 mm aux input!
reviews.author: Corndog
reviews.content: Sure, it's a bit weighty, but I'd rather that and have nice, beefy sound, than to have it be light and have a less substantial sound. But you may differ. If you are one of those people, you may prefer the Motion Boom Plus by Soundcore. I got a chance to test out both in person, and personally, like many, I went with the Blast.The Motion Boom Plus can be tuned for an elegant sound, but its limited EQ in the app kills what could be much better. I was able to get richer, lower reaching bass out of it using a 3rd party app, but it took much work what was existent out off the box with the Blast - and much more substantial at that! The retro-looking RGB side lights are icing on the cake. Very cool to look at, and adds a unique effect.As for sound, I usually opt for flat, neutral tunes when it comes to my monitors and headphones, but I wanted a fun, boomy "travel" speaker (more like 'road-trip speaker) that was competent with the bass. Not only is it clean and punchy, it can reach down surprisingly low for such small drivers. The mids and highs are nothing to write home about, but they aren't terrible. They're serviceable. Mids are a bit recessed, dry, and resist drastic tuning, but can be slightly brightened to bring the tracks alive. Could be better, but not bad, and doesn't ruin the sound of the speaker. I'll also add here that I wouldn't have purchased this speaker if it did not have the 3.5 mm aux input, so good on Tribit for including that.Battery life is also phenomenal, but prepare to lose just a tiny bit in the power of the sound when unplugged. I honestly prefer that approach, as I value sound quality over portability. If it's relatively close while on battery, but gets a nice boost plugged in, hooray for that! In the end, I suppose it's how you look at it; lose power when unplugged for portability vs get a boost when plugged in - I see it the second way because I'm used to the philosophy that there is always a sacrifice for portability.Right now the Stormbox Blast is priced 40% off its original price at $155.98. That's awesome, especially when you consider that the less capable, yet lighter Motion Boom Plus is price $5 more. It's really going to come down to your preferences and personal needs. But if it's for a more powerful sound, a flashier look and presence, then this one is going to be it in this price range.

reviews.title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great initial quality
reviews.author: SuperBlindGirl
reviews.content: Writing this review from one blind person's perspective.I have purchased other Tribit speakers, namely the storm box. I was very happy with it, so when I wanted some thing bigger and louder for outdoors, I gravitated toward this blast. Based on my experience with the storm box, which is a smaller less powerful speaker, I was hoping the blast would afford the same features. There were some similarities, but some drawbacks as well. It is not a larger version of the storm box. It does have somewhat of a similar feel, same shape only larger, but sports a handle on the top as it is much heavier than I would have expected. I assume this is due to the significantly larger battery which allows for long playtime, lighting, and the ability to charge other devices from the speaker. Well it is noticeably heavy, it is not overwhelmingly heavy. Unlike the storm box, do not expect 360° sound from this speaker. It only projects forward. What I liked about the storm box were large easy to find volume and play pause buttons. The buttons to control the speaker are on the top in front of the handle in a row. While they do have some tactile markings, they are not as pronounced as the storm box, and are much smaller buttons. They can easily blend together. I would have liked to see bigger and better marked buttons considering the large size of this speaker. Similarly to the storm box, the controls only allow for volume up and down and play pause. There are not controls to skip tracks or fast forward. I really would like to see this feature added to their line of products as it would be extremely helpful, so is one drawback to the brand. One cool thing is that you can download the Tribit app, which I did on my iPhone, and this allows for full control of the speaker, including lights, equalizer, and volume controls. I have been using the speaker outside, and I think that is where it excels. It definitely sounds good inside, but definitely seems made for the outdoors. I appreciate that it is water resistant, and it has decently deep base which I also appreciate. The lighting has two different modes, which with my extremely low vision I can barely make out but I'm sure keep things interesting for those who can see. You can control the lights either from the app or using the button on the speaker itself. You can also turn on and off the base boost on the speaker itself or in the app. There are more equalizer options within the app . I don't have much of a very discerning ear I guess, because I have a hard time distinguishing between the difference of bass boost and party modes, but the sound quality is good. The biggest and best surprise for me was that when I used Bluetooth to connect this speaker to my iPhone to play music, the music played on the speaker, but voiceover was only coming out of my phone. I actually love this because it allows me to control the music from my phone accessibly but not interrupt the music. I wish every speaker would do this! my storm box speakers don't seem to have this functionality and I have not experienced it with any other brands of speakers. This made me very happy! I was able to purchase the speaker on sale, which made the price tag a lot more palatable. So my recommendation would be to watch for that! it is definitely overall a solid speaker and worth checking out, especially if you have vision issues.

reviews.content: I have been eying up the JBL BOOMBOX 3 for a while since I love my Charge 4 but I wanted something that filled the yard with sound and carried good bass. The Boombox 3 seemed to be the ticket but man, that price is high.I stumbled onto a review for this Tribit StormBox on YouTube from German guy who had these two side by side on an open basketball court while his son was zooming around a few RC cars. He switched between these two testing the volume, bass, using different music and the difference was remarkable. Unfortunately that video has disappeared but I was impressed enough to look into this and give it a try and when I saw this had a $40 coupon bringing it to $160 I jumped. I was not disappointed!The sound is great, the battery is phenomenal (without running the LEDs and at about 50-75% volume), and a few people who have heard it were very impressed. I had three long 6-8 hours days in the yard and each night forgot to take it in when I only had one and charge it and on the 4th day I thought I might be in trouble lasting all day but checked the app and it still had 40% charge!I loved it so much I purchased a second one so I could run them in stereo mode as a left and right speaker! It also works in 'serial' mode so both speakers are connected and both playing the same music in stereo if they are spread apart too far to have a left and right speaker.UPDATE!!! I thought is was able to play in 'serial' mode which the speaker said it was in but it is still only left and right when connected. I didn't really notice it with the music I was playing but caught on after some music with more separation. I reached out to Tribit on this and they said it only paired in stereo mode but not at all a deal breaker but it would be nice to have this feature.The nice touch for using them together is that once linked they remember the mode you are connected in (stereo or serial) so when you turn them on they link together again automatically. The volume of both is controlled by my phone so they both go up and down with the one control and if you turn one off when connected the other powers down as well. The only slightly negative things I have with this is sometimes if my phone is on me in my pocket and I am working at a lower level in the yard behind a retaining wall the Bluetooth can get a little spotty but works fine when I leave the yard and go in the house and even stays connected if I go into the front yard.The other thing I would like to see is some sort of visual indicator of the battery life on the speaker itself, maybe adding that as an option when cycling the LED modes. Dont ask me how the do it, but they do.The wireless reaction time from my phone is instantaneous on this boombox (unlike the micro 2, which has about a .5 second delay).I have been trying to get my computer speakers to work on my tv because there isnt any bass since the speaker bar wireless bass/rears went out, so I hooked this Tribit boombox to my TV ! There is a little delay when my tv is paired with the Tribit, but I know its from me having an old tv, with wireless 3.x or 4.0 max, and also with 2 sound bars hooked up to it (man I wish my 1st sound bar bass/rear didnt go out on me. I cant afford another $700 to $1100 for just a sound bar bass and rear).Anyway, this Tribit is 'almost' what I was looking for, so here comes the Negs/Wishes.]There is NO Remote control. Why not? A remote control goes a LONG way on a limited product like this.Did I say this thing is heavy? It really is. Or something, even rubber handle over the plastic would make hauling this around much nicer.Did I say Limited? Yes, I did. This tribit does 2 things, play music from app and lights. Thats it. No Radio (I know, only us old folk listen to the radio). No cd player. No Time/Day/Date etc (would be nice to be able to use this as an Alarm clock. USB port for thumb drives? Port for sd/micro sdhc cards?Power bank? What device is NOT more portable for a power bank? Or even less pricey? Seems this was just one of those Checkbox 'features' because there arent any features (mostly because that would require a remote control for? maybe).AUX In? Hello, phones dont have a 3.5mm port anymore. Or are we supposed to tie ourselves to the Tribit, yet again, and carry a 3.5mm to usb-c cable around? Maybe we could put it in the Tribit carry bag...Oh, wait, there isnt one. Heh.Overall, for what I use it for, its almost perfect. And it seems W-K is going down this road now also with their new lineup (I was choosing between this and the squared W-K back before the new sleeker W-K came out). Except for a remote control, just to turn up or lower volume, and turn it on off (basically a remote that has the buttons on top of the Stormbox, this thing is almost perfect for me, except when I have to lug it somewhere else in the room. Tribit does 2 things VERY well, and those are Sound quality which this has, and real Time mentioned on how long it runs, which is usually on the lower side rather than the higher side. And Tech Support, so 3 things. I havent needed support for this Stormbox, so its 2 for now.Recommended?Yes. Oh, also if you want to use it for your tv speakers instead of the tinny sounding wimpy ones that come with tv's nowadays, lol.I almost gave it 5 stars, it is that good, but w/o a remote control and very limited use, I just cant give it a 5.

Buy if you want something loud and cheap, don't buy for your shower or outdoor adventures.I bought this speaker due to its high rankings among various reviewers, and am blown away by the sound quality for a speaker around 1/3 the price of its closest competitor (the JBL Boombox series).My friends and I did a side-by-side sound test of the Tribit Stormbox Blast vs a JBL Boombox 2 and found them to be nearly indistinguishable at high volume. Both speakers play loud enough to be uncomfortable for extended indoor use and experience no noticeable distortion or clipping at maximum volume. Default EQ settings of the Tribit vs the JBL are different but both speakers allow for enough customization to suit most users' needs.To sound that good for 1/3 the cost, however, some cuts did have to be made. The two most noticeable are the build quality of the speaker and its low-volume performance. The Tribit speaker is heavy and feels as bulky as it sounds, but is constructed out of cheap-feeling plastic compared to the "luxurious" fabric and rubber overwrap on the JBL Boombox. This makes the speaker easier to dry, put stickers on, or attach third-party mounts to but does look and feel cheap.Low-volume performance is also significantly worse than that of the JBL, mostly due to the Tribit only having 16 volume levels. The gaps between them at low volumes are HUGE compared to those on smaller speakers (think five or six levels on something you could fit in your hand) and I personally find many situations where the only volume options are too quiet or too loud for low-volume use. This can be combatted by disabling Bluetooth absolute volume on your source device or using a source which does not support absolute volume (AUX input or older Bluetooth device). Both the Tribit and the JBL sound less clear and refined at lower volume than most smaller speakers, this is not a design flaw but rather an inherent property of speaker sizing.Another major drawback of the Tribit speaker compared to its more expensive competitors is its poor water resistance. The speaker is rated at IPX7 and can be submerged in water for short periods of time but will malfunction if exposed to splashes or spray for an extended period of time (use outdoors in the rain, inside a shower enclosure, etc). This malfunction usually involves the speaker quickly increasing to maximum volume while the controls fail to respond to inputs and appears to be caused by the use of a paper-based adhesive gasket to secure the control panel's rubber insert into the speaker body. For my use case this is a HUGE drawback but is something I am willing to deal with given the speaker's incredible performance as a high-volume boombox.Other aspects of the speaker mostly work as advertised. I have used the app to update firmware and it has worked without issue. Stereo mode works as well, with no apparent audio delay and full synchronization of the controls and lighting between the speakers. The lack of aptX support for a device with Bluetooth 5.3 hardware is quite unusual but I cannot hear a difference in audio quality, at least when streaming music through Spotify on a run-of-the-mill Android phone. I have yet to fully test battery life but the advertised figures appear accurate, at least based off the battery level shown in the app.In conclusion, I would recommend this speaker to anyone looking for a LOUD Bluetooth speaker, assuming your use case won't involve getting the speaker very wet. If you need a speaker which can be continuously used in wet environments, consider the JBL Boombox instead.Notes:- Ingress protection ratings are cumulative (e.g. a device rated at IPX5 is also rated at IPX4 and so on) only through level 6. Although most devices which can handle short-term submersion can also handle continuous splashes and sprays, it is possible to create one which cannot. Tribit is not making incorrect claims about the water resistance of their speaker (The Stormbox Blast does appear to meet IPX7 standards) but is rather advertising it in a way which may be misleading to some consumers.- Several of the issues with this speaker could be addressed through a firmware update, adding support for aptX Bluetooth audio, increasing the number of volume levels, etc. Given that the speaker has already received several firmware updates and is relatively new, I expect Tribit to improve on its functionality through future updates.- The water resistance of the speaker could be massively enhanced with some modifications. Several teardowns and analyses are available on the Internet as of the writing of this review, and the speaker is designed well from a water-resistance standpoint minus the issues with the control panel. I personally believe that a "control panel protector" could be installed on the top of the speaker and that this would allow it to handle splashes and sprays without issue.- The built-in power supply inside the speaker is massively convenient (makes the charger MUCH smaller than that of the JBL boombox) and is powerful enough to run the speaker at maximum volume continuously. Some other competitors (namely the Anker Soundcore Motion Boom Plus) do not have enough input power capacity to keep up with sustained high-volume use while plugged in. This is a big plus for the Tribit if your speaker will be used in a gym, dance studio, party house, or other situation where it'll rarely see low-volume or battery-operated use.- Most Bluetooth speakers which are covered in lights look cheap and tacky. Tribit does their lighting well, it is not obnoxious and can be turned off if desired. Several other reviewers have seen this as an issue but I personally have no problem with it.

reviews.title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Its heavy and loud
reviews.author: Keon B. Billings
reviews.content: I was skeptical about the battery, life claims, and about the alleged base that this thing puts out. I can now officially say humbly and with respect that this thing delivers even more so than some reviewers claimed. The base is impressively deep and rich given the size of the speakers, and the battery life went for several hours for me without losing volume. I cannot attest to its acclaimed battery life, but it ran several hour for me, and I am more than happy with its performance.Don't go getting any bright ideas this single speaker can power your house party by itself fill the entire room with sound, etc. etc. It is definitely loud, it definitely have a lot of base for its size, and the battery life is impressive. However, please be realistic in your expectations. When you blast any system, no matter who makes it, Bose, JBL, Sony, beats, it doesn't matter. The higher you push the volume, the more battery it uses, and the shorter your playtime will be. That's just a basic fact of electronics and battery life.That said, this unknown company Tribit have a gem on their hands with this speaker box. I highly recommend it.As for the weight of this thing, I can only assume that it's weight is due to the charge circuit and electronics is inside the unit. Most portable units have a single USB connection that charges the device from an external charge adapter or some other unit plugged into the wall. In the case of this device, all those electronics are packaged inside the unit and seeing that it's enclosed, I'm pretty sure they use more beefy components than normal. That plus the accompanying batteries I believe added up to the weight. Knowing this information, I am more than happy because now I don't have to look for a charger adapter to charge my Bluetooth speaker because it's already inside, I just need to plug it in.If you have not already figured it out, I highly recommend the speaker. It's plenty loud, it's got lots of headroom for highs and lows, and they have great battery life. What more could you possibly want from a Bluetooth speaker?
